urls.title: It’s been a year since the Kentucky tornadoes. For some in Mayfield, recovery far from over
urls.description: In July, the state's attention turned to the killing floods in Eastern Kentucky, but the wounds remained for many who survived in the candle factory.

data.text:
In the third and final part of By Candlelight, we learn what's happened to each of the tornado survivors @jrbullington followed this year.

Prepare for a rollercoaster ride of emotions...
https://t.co/pAEq4lreVC
@kjemoore15 @The74 @courierjournal @NewYorker @RachelAviv Thank you so much, Kathy!

Poe also says the board needs to be working with higher ed. 

"Are they continuing to teach by a mechanism that the state legislature said we're no longer going to fund?"

"We need to push .. teacher colleges that they need to change their methodology of training teachers."

Teachers need training and not enough have taken advantage of the free LETRS @KyDeptofEd is offering, says board member @dr_poe.

"The legislature needs to incentivize this to move us farther and faster."

In an ongoing KBE meeting, @kycommissioner concedes the Read to Succeed Act ($15M annually) is "probably not enough" to turn the tide of Kentucky's reading rates.

"It requires a much more significant investment than what Kentucky is making."

Thanks so much @The74 @gtoppo for including Between the Lines on your 2022 Jealousy List!

16 Essential Articles About Students & Schools We Wish We Had Published This Year https://t.co/jzz8vt0URE

urls.title: Midterm election: Who will win Kentucky's US Senate seat — Rand Paul or Charles Booker?
urls.description: U.S. Sen. Rand Paul was expected to sail in red state Kentucky, but Democrat Charles Booker was hoping to score a huge upset in the midterm election

data.text: RT @courierjournal: Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul defeats Democrat Charles Booker https://t.co/o5SqMFwKiO

One thing, though, was clear on my visit. 

There was just one book her son was excited to read to me. 

Can you guess which one?

🐘

So what should we make of this? Can there be room for both types of books? Or do predictable readers like these encourage too many bad habits?

Imagine being my friend, the parent, who has no clue. 

What should she do with her son? She doesn’t know. https://t.co/K0sXyaTz7M

When teachers use books like this, they’re typically more focused on whether a child UNDERSTANDS the story than if they can DECODE it. 

Decoding may be part of it, but it is not the main goal. https://t.co/RxP5QMNpQD

Here’s another book he came home with. 

This, like the bug book, has words a beginning kindergartener wouldn’t be able to sound out. And again, he’s being encouraged to read based on pictures. https://t.co/47tFR7i0P4

Compare. 

See how, in the bug book, an early reader would need to know more complex phonics rules to sound out leaf or flower? That’s why a kid would turn to pictures (esp if they’re being encouraged to!) https://t.co/t1A17MSxuh

Go, Pam! is a decodable reader. 

The book is meant for readers practicing the short a sound. 

Yes, there are pictures. But a beginning reader who’s learning initial phonics rules could approach these words with confidence. They would be advised to “sound it out.” https://t.co/W2zESXvVL4
Now let’s take a look at Go, Pam! https://t.co/SirIjDg40i

This is considered to be part of a teaching strategy  called “3 cueing.”

The strategy, associated with balanced literacy, is under national scrutiny. https://t.co/Mm8Ia0PRNW

The second thing you’ll notice are the labels on the illustrations. 

This is explicitly encouraging a child to look at a picture when they come across an unknown word. 
 
This is the habit of a poor reader, research has shown. https://t.co/ntbQiZj4kR

Critics say predictable readers don’t teach children to read — but instead teach them to memorize. 

“This bug is on…This bug is on…This bug is on…” https://t.co/WgWlZzImHM

Let’s start with Look for Bugs. 

There are two things going on here. 

First, you’ll notice the sentences repeat throughout the story, except for the last word. 

This is called a predictable reader. https://t.co/lLooR5s4tc

They both have colorful illustrations and the titles both feel age appropriate for very early readers. 

But that’s where their similarities end. 

Their differences are important. Because they illustrate a critical piece of the Science of Reading debate. https://t.co/RmKUXJ04k6

🧵 A tale of two books. 

I visited a friend over the weekend. Her son is in kindergarten. 

He brought each of these books home from school. https://t.co/5IFbd5dwZQ
@MarcusGreenWDRB Thank you for reading, Marcus!
Was finding this very cute and sweet until I got to Lucas and now I’m just sad https://t.co/JeJ4BxfqTE
@lilyalta @freep love this

urls.description: For years leading up to the pandemic, we regularly ripped off paid homage to Bloomberg Businessweek’s “Jealousy List” — the outlet’s annual tip of the hat to the best journalism and analysis published by competitors that year. (You can dive into their memorable 2021 edition right here.) Now, after a two-year absence, we’re looking to […]

tweets.text: .@mandy_mclaren's devastating and consequential series on Kentucky’s bad and worsening reading results was a project we envied this year. Read the @courierjournal series & see our full jealousy list https://t.co/TlhRncq69t

I wanted to highlight some stories I did this year that cover reading--including the complex and multi-layered reading overhauls in two states with some of the lowest historical reading rates, Tennessee and Mississippi, and a reading explainer for parents. Links and info below:

Not sure if @the74's content is the GF here, 🙄but super clear why these stories turned our head. For me esp., @courierjournal's @mandy_mclaren's Ky reading investigation & @NewYorker's @RachelAviv exposing kid glove treatment of affluent white parents accused of abuse. https://t.co/HTLXgP69Hj

Teachers need training and not enough have taken advantage of the free LETRS @KyDeptofEd is offering, says board member @dr_poe.

"The legislature needs to incentivize this to move us farther and faster."

In an ongoing KBE meeting, @kycommissioner concedes the Read to Succeed Act ($15M annually) is "probably not enough" to turn the tide of Kentucky's reading rates.

"It requires a much more significant investment than what Kentucky is making."

"We may act like we’re OK, but we’re not. And I don’t know how to get back to where I was." 
An incredible and necessary read from @jrbullington 

https://t.co/vvdqm7JQEG via @courierjournal

@mandy_mclaren I hope you’ve had some positive self talk this week, Mandy. You’re making big impacts for kids, teachers, parents, and the future. 🙌🏻😊
Thank you @mandy_mclaren for your investigative reporting! When we know better, we must DO better 👏🏾👏🏾 https://t.co/VXJ4uBUGdc

urls.title: Midterm election: Who will win Kentucky's US Senate seat — Rand Paul or Charles Booker?
urls.description: U.S. Sen. Rand Paul was expected to sail in red state Kentucky, but Democrat Charles Booker was hoping to score a huge upset in the midterm election

tweets.text: Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul defeats Democrat Charles Booker https://t.co/o5SqMFwKiO

So what should we make of this? Can there be room for both types of books? Or do predictable readers like these encourage too many bad habits?

Imagine being my friend, the parent, who has no clue. 

What should she do with her son? She doesn’t know. https://t.co/K0sXyaTz7M

When teachers use books like this, they’re typically more focused on whether a child UNDERSTANDS the story than if they can DECODE it. 

Decoding may be part of it, but it is not the main goal. https://t.co/RxP5QMNpQD

Here’s another book he came home with. 

This, like the bug book, has words a beginning kindergartener wouldn’t be able to sound out. And again, he’s being encouraged to read based on pictures. https://t.co/47tFR7i0P4

Compare. 

See how, in the bug book, an early reader would need to know more complex phonics rules to sound out leaf or flower? That’s why a kid would turn to pictures (esp if they’re being encouraged to!) https://t.co/t1A17MSxuh

Go, Pam! is a decodable reader. 

The book is meant for readers practicing the short a sound. 

Yes, there are pictures. But a beginning reader who’s learning initial phonics rules could approach these words with confidence. They would be advised to “sound it out.” https://t.co/W2zESXvVL4
Now let’s take a look at Go, Pam! https://t.co/SirIjDg40i

This is considered to be part of a teaching strategy  called “3 cueing.”

The strategy, associated with balanced literacy, is under national scrutiny. https://t.co/Mm8Ia0PRNW

The second thing you’ll notice are the labels on the illustrations. 

This is explicitly encouraging a child to look at a picture when they come across an unknown word. 
 
This is the habit of a poor reader, research has shown. https://t.co/ntbQiZj4kR

Critics say predictable readers don’t teach children to read — but instead teach them to memorize. 

“This bug is on…This bug is on…This bug is on…” https://t.co/WgWlZzImHM

Let’s start with Look for Bugs. 

There are two things going on here. 

First, you’ll notice the sentences repeat throughout the story, except for the last word. 

This is called a predictable reader. https://t.co/lLooR5s4tc

They both have colorful illustrations and the titles both feel age appropriate for very early readers. 

But that’s where their similarities end. 

Their differences are important. Because they illustrate a critical piece of the Science of Reading debate. https://t.co/RmKUXJ04k6

🧵 A tale of two books. 

I visited a friend over the weekend. Her son is in kindergarten. 

He brought each of these books home from school. https://t.co/5IFbd5dwZQ

urls.title: BETWEEN THE LINES
urls.description: Why Kentucky's kids can't read and who's to blame.

https://t.co/0cjPpg6CiL
